posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9640282
[cont]

The translation introduces a glitch at some point mid way through the game and you'll probably need the help of savestates and/or the guide to get out of it as the player gets sent into a graphically glitched area. Also don't use the "exp counter" patch, it doesn't work.
Also the end boss is really challenging, I could only beat it with the following strategy (the strategy told in the guide is terrible): go to the glitchy point mentioned just above, there is a computer that lets you re-distribute your stats. Forget about agility, for the 2 guys focus on attack, for the girl on wisdom (magical attack power). The protag should have the psycho sword, while the girl should spam Thunder (and not Thunder3, the MP cost isn't worth the difference). Use Psyshell at the start of the fight for increased def. Forget about the robot, use it for healing items and then let it die. Have as many Vitaron and Brainer items as you can in the inventory.

Not a bad game per se but I hope you're ready for a lot of grind, cryptic puzzles, and an unfinished (even glitchy) translation.

Other tips:
-The battle msg speed is VERY slow by default: press select in the menu to remedy that.
-Spells not specified in the FAQ:
Wall: increase def for a single character
Inji: increase chance of escaping battle
-A common trick for RPGs of the time: you can avoid battle in the overworld by opening the menu and closing it every 4-5 steps. This also seems to work in dungeons, however dungeons also have set battles on some tiles you can not avoid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642727
>>9642476
I give it point because I think the difficulty of the western NES version was spot on for me yes, but not just that. Exploration and possible unlinearilty, the adventure mechanics, god tier music, still images of enemies that look dynamic, characters and story that managed to draw me in despite the low amount of text, and much more.
People in the west only praise DQ1 as "father of the JRPG", but really most of those other RPGs owe as much (if not more) to 2 than to 1; so there is that too, being the first doing so many things for the genre. In the DQ anniversary doc on youtube they do acknowledge DQ2's legacy.

Few examples of why I think DQ2 is well designed:
- the allies and the way they join the party. Everything is made to make you realize they were going through their own adventures of their own while you were. This gives them weight and personality and puts everyone on the same level. How many RPGs have each character put on the same level of importance like that? Certainly not DQ3.
- The way towns work like hubs. You usually use the same town in between several small quests; either that or there is a good reason to come back to the town later on. This makes the world feel organic, real; vs the tired routine "each area is composed of one town, one dungeon, clear that, reach next area, repeat" which DQ3 started.
- The adventure elements, namely the treasure hunting; DQ2 probably started the "you must find X number of magical key items as a goal" trope for jRPGs (unless you count Zelda as an RPG), but unlike later/other use of that trope in which the key item is merely a meaningless token for denoting that you beat a dungeon; here you must go through adventure game mechanics to acquire them, acquire clues, solve puzzle, beat dungeons too sure but not only, and almost each one is acquired differently. Again this makes the items and the world feel real and you can imagine what happened to each item to get to the point that they are now.

My philosophy on this has changed so much because back in the day I would never have guessed that I'd pay for an old video game with triple digits but in recent memory I own a few like Radiant Silvergun and Bangai-O!, it's all in the eye of the beholder.
Realistically I can emulate those games easy but I wanted to own them and that's the value people see in them and knowing I have the money to afford them without really causing financial harm to myself I'm okay with making those kind of purchases, if I wasn't I probably wouldn't have bought them.
It's the hobby, people can collect anything and it all seems pointless and retarded in the grand scheme, you're just gonna die one day and everything will rot away and turn into dust.
I just like collecting games and playing them at the end of the day.
Do I think most games with high prices are valid? Fuck no, but the market has fluctuated so much in the last few years alone that it's a fucking mad world out there, no one could have predicted what Covid was going to fuck with and on top of that, nostalgia-baiting is what's practically saturating the market of tons of mediums, not just video games.
For me, it's easy to emulate and play games, nothing wrong with that and it's clearly the best option to just even play the game.
I like to collect personally and it's extremely hard to validate regardless of what I say but that could be any hobby really.
Hobbies are fun but there are extremes to every hobby that you either acknowledge exists and not really care about or give attention to and proceed to enjoy it the way you like, or you learn to work around the issues.
High prices in retro gaming has kinda ruined why I originally got into it because as a kid I couldn't afford new games and would buy second hand older games to have more games to play for much cheaper.
It is what it is, you either cope with it or don't and work around it, but complaining about it seems pointless and redundant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9637361
>most powerful home device for 3d graphics
Technically, since it's restricted to fixed point math with no depth buffer, it's probably not. 3D math was handled by various ASIC chips rather than raw CPU power. But the result was impressive, regardless. Matrox Impression had a superior polygonal and shading capability as well as true 3D math, but no texture mapping.

It's just like how 8-bit and 16-bit consoles outperformed $2000 IBM computers at 2D games back in the 80s. PCs were incredibly powerful but not engineered for gaming, PC gaming had only became a thing by the mid 90s. In the 80s, we had C64 and the Amiga, but the home computer market was dead by the 1990s thus there was nothing stopping consoles from becoming the most optimized device for gaming. Still, consoles still had one weakness, which is the lack of hard drive and a really tiny amount of RAM. System Shock couldn't possibly run on the PS1.

>>9642602
>More pathetic than a Jaguar launch game.


For a game from 1993, the jaguar does have some interesting capabilities. Cyber morph did look impressive for its day. But, apparently Atari made some cutbacks in the hardware that gimped the machine?

Jaguar games:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D_PGqVbCvU4&t=485s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C44xYXycDzE&t=234s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_kLG8v3O_UE
Noe 32X games:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwEih8efjVA&t=506s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KhbL1md2QL4&t=5s
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i_Jxu9Z3t9E
For the hell of it, the 3DO:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GGXytmFQHns&t=1s
https://youtu.be/zozFVGNzIpQ?t=490
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wuvg9L45nKE

The 32x, the 3DO and the Atari Jaguar all have their ups and downs. the 32x being an add-on for an existing console, and having to rely on some of the 16bit components. The jaguar does have pretty good 2D capabilities and can do flat shaded polygons and scaling sprites pretty well. The machine also has a Motorola 68000, which devs had to rely on. The 3DO is an ARM7 powered machine with the ability to render quads, it also has some good video mixing modes, 2D capabilities seem questionable. Gex can barely handle 30fps at times.

if you look at the game files to see how it prioritizes alien missions it's actually quite cute and you can see how the game designers planned everything out. different alien species have different probabilities of doing a particular mission, and different regions get different mission probabilities.

>but alien bases are rare there because aliens prefer to put those in more sparsely populated areas
>Southeast Asia gets a lot of abduction missions due to its huge population density

>>9625207
>never do nighttime crashed UFOs
i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing so you don't have to worry about bringing them down, and if you're worried about night missions you can usually wait a few hours before actually sending your skyranger in.
i usually don't even consider shooting down ufos until i'm confident my main base(s) can handle an attack, i have plasma beams and the aliens start spamming more missions, maybe they're infiltrating germany and i don't want half a dozen ufos tanking my score during a particularly bad month, or maybe i'm being cheeky and i want to nuke a terror ship in january or something. ymmv

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9631206
>i'm not nearly as experienced with tftd so i can't really provide input on it
It's generally similar with the following important differences

>aliens will do shipping route attacks starting in April--these can have any alien race on them
>artifact sites will start appearing in July--these are always a Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew, and you cannot duck out of them due to a massive point penalty (-1000 points for failing to complete the mission, -3000 for ignoring it).
>the game will generate 12 artifact sites, one for each region of the globe
>colonies are always Tasoth/Aquatoid mixed crew in part 1 and Lobstermen in part 2, but the race that constructed the colony will send supply ships to it
>on lower difficulty settings you will get more port/island attacks and fewer shipping route/artifact sites
>in infiltration missions, none of the alien infiltration fleet lands--until you get advanced craft weapons you will not be able to shoot down most of the USOs
>the TFTD terror ship (Battleship) has more powerful weapons than the battleship (Dreadnought) so while you could easily shoot down a EU Terror Ship with two Interceptors+Avalanche missiles, it's extremely risky (but still possible) to attempt it in TFTD--since it also never lands, the only way to fight one is to shoot it down
>in base defense missions, up to 5 aliens will spawn inside your base
>the Barracuda has shorter range than Interceptor and can't fly as far before running out of fuel

another little pointer is that when fighting landed or crashed UFOs there's a certain probability that aliens will spawn inside the ship or outside of it. this depends on their rank, but generally:

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9631206
>i don't recommend shooting down ufos in the first place, even if you're willing to accept getting less rewards from them, there's still a flat 20% chance of the game generating a free alien retaliation mission every single time you shoot a ufo down on superhuman (it's only 4% on beginner, but still) - most ufos generated by every single mission (retaliation ufos being the biggest exception) *will* land at least once while they're doing their thing

https://www.ufopaedia.org/index.php/MISSIONS.DAT

Most UFOs on most missions land except during retaliation. Small scouts only land during base construction or harvest missions (small scout #1 on harvest missions lands, #2 doesn't). The first terror ship on terror missions does not land either. Shooting a UFO down of course may spawn a retaliation mission, which is a 50% chance of occuring either in the region the shootdown was in or the region where the X-COM craft that shot it down is based. If a retaliation scout passes over your base, it may become revealed to the aliens, and the odds go up the more facilities the base has.

If you shoot down the Battleship attacking the base with an X-COM craft, or they don't find your base at all, the retaliation mission ends. If the aliens do attack and you beat them in a base defense mission, the retaliation mission is immediately restarted with a new Small Scout and they'll keep going for it until they fail to find your base or you shoot down the incoming Battleship. if you shoot it down with base defense weapons it produces the infamous bug with endlessly attacking Battleships.

in TFTD they made it that only Lobsterman officers allow you to unlock T'Leth Or Bust because in EU it was too easy to grab a Floater commander in the first two months of the game.

posts.com: I'm stuck on the part where you have to capture an alien commander. Do they look any different or do I just need to try to capture anyone who is hanging out in an important room?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9638543
If you're fighting a Battleship, the commander is on the bridge and will usually be carrying a Blaster Launcher, although early game it's more likely Heavy Plasma. In alien bases he always carries Heavy Plasma and will be in the central command room, though on Superhuman he'll spawn outside someplace due to lack of spawn nodes and it can be real hard to identify him without a Mind Probe.

Weapon loadouts for base defense missions are same as the Battleship, meaning the commander will likely have a Blaster Launcher, although he can spawn anywhere and again be very hard to identify without a Mind Probe. It's generally easiest to capture one from a Battleship as you can guarantee he'll always be on the bridge.

Note that you will also need a live alien leader to complete the research tree for Cydonia or Bust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Battleships are easy to clear since you can just shoot up the central grav lift at aliens above and if you have Blaster Bombs, you can also fire them up there. Beware that aliens will fire Blaster Bombs down the grav lift at you as well. In the original games you could shoot a ranged weapon up the lifts to easily pick off aliens on the floor above you, but OXC makes it that the aliens can also shoot down the lifts at you which they used to not be able to do.

Also note the room I marked with an X. That room has a spawn node, and the large-sized terrorists (Reaper, Cyberdisc, and Sectopod) can spawn in there and get stuck and unable to leave. For the latter two you can be in for a nasty surprise when you go into that room and one of them is in there and facing you.

>>9638760
The hallways there usually have a couple aliens in them, these would be soldiers and terrorists. the medic hangs out in the room with the disco floor, and the engineer(s) in the small engine rooms in the landing legs. on the top floor is the officers and navigators. as usually the case, some of the lower ranking aliens will spawn outside the ship and some inside it.

Note that the engineers and officers can carry Blaster Launchers, and the probability of them carrying them goes up with each month of the game until month 9 when they all have them. on Superhuman you can end up late game with as many as six aliens packing them, so beware. by that point of course you should have a couple Blaster Launcher guys of your own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One other thing to note. Not all aliens have all ranks, in fact only Sectoids and Floaters have each rank. For the other three species, the missing ranks are replaced by an extra soldier or leader. These will follow the same spawn rules but have different aggressiveness, so if you for example fight a Muton Battleship, the officers get replaced by soldiers who have high aggression levels and will leave their post to go and attack you instead of just sitting in place on the bridge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You'll want to eventually get psionics, and the best way to do this is to bag a Sectoid leader from a larger UFO. Of course he'll be mind raping you the entire mission but...about mind control. It depends on line of sight. The aliens can only target soldiers they can see, and they'll always attack the weakest soldier that is visible to them. This is why different soldiers will be targeted at different times.

When you have a Psy Lab built, you can put up to 10 soldiers in it to train them, but this will take a month during which time they're effectively out of action (you can still use them on missions but why are you putting them in harm's way?) At first you just want to determine what soldiers have good psionic strength and which ones are crap. The good ones you may leave in the Psy Lab for additional months to build their psionic skills while the shitty ones can be used against non-psionic aliens. Or you can just take them into action and practice on aliens--each attempt at mind control counts towards your psy skill; doesn't have to succeed, just the attempt is enough. While taking over Floaters and Mutons is easy, the tougher aliens need a much stronger team.

When you go to Cydonia, make sure all soldiers have a minimum of 60 psionic strength and really, you want 80 or more.

I find it interesting that all the complaints people in here have towards Jak/whatever other PS2 mascot platformers are similar to my complaints with most Nintendo 3D platformers
...could it be that we're all blinded by nostalgia and that all of these games have aged horribly, but we're able to look past it with the games we played as played as kids because we view them with rose tinted glasses and are used to their garbage controls and janky mechanics?
I'm not implying Jak and Daxter is the peak of video games, but I personally find it much easier to approach than a lot of the Nintendo games I missed as a kid.
To be fair, playing them now that I've gotten older I don't feel like I missed out on much, none of them were good enough to bother playing past the first hour or two, including all the "classics" that it seems everyone unanimously agrees are some of the best games ever made like SM64.
I imagine people who grew up with those games feel the same way about Jak, Crash or Ratchet or whatever the fuck.

>>9641412

It's like the straight opposite of Banjo desu, Banjo was collectathon for the sake of collectathon, and padded the shit out of the length with extra shit to collect for no real reason.

This has only 1 main collectable and all the sub-collectables are basically currencies that eventually give you a main collectable. It's a lot more focussed but in the end that means you only need to collect like half the shit in the game to reach the ending. You can finish it in probably 3-4 hours casually, and about 8-12 for 100%.

Also I can't think of any other platformer that did the seamless map design this game had. No loading screens, start to finish, one side of the map to the other, everything links up into a coherent world.

They already had an analog flight stick long before either. The dual analog was their own take on the analog controller. Looks like sony didn't steal ideas, they were merely influenced by and improved upon them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9640670
It's because it's simply not that fun. Metal Blade kills nearly everything, but the buster also works wonders, while the rest of the weapons ding off almost every enemy and are barely even useful. Most of the stages are really linear, secrets are easy and basic to get, actually challenging and interesting sections (like the long Heat Man disappearing blocks section) has glitches that screw them up, the bosses are either really basic or a pain in the ass and the game bothers more with it's presentation and style (awesome looking wily castle, alien wily hologram boss, mecha dragon) than substance (every wily fortress boss except the boobeam being extremely basic and uninteresting, while the boobeam is more annoying than anything because knowing the solution makes it into another boring boss you do the exact same way and move on). Mega Man to me is all about experimenting on replays - what if I use this weapon here? Or against this enemy? What if it will work better? Or what if there's a secret here? 2 fails at that - it's a game that's really easy to beat if you do it the exact same way each time while barely even using the weapons, but it limits experimentation heavily and because of that, it's way less replayable. That said, Quick Man and his stage is awesome.

Before making a thread proper asking about I will ask here:

Has anyone seen a version of Super Street Fighter II X for Dreamcast which was modded to use the PC version soundtrack?
I will do this myself if it comes down to it but it would save me a lot of trouble if someone has already done the work.

So far I have found three custom sound track releases

-a version that uses all the CPS1 music
-a version that uses the Overclocked Remix AST
-a version that uses various remixes from a variety of sources (this one is the ps1 version)

Seems like an obvious thing to do because there is no good version of ST which uses this soundtrack which is actually very nice to listen to. So far it is exclusive to the DOS version of ST released by gametek.
https://youtu.be/m_9s5gbr-U4

Note: this is not the 3do remix (actually first appeared on the FM Towns), this is a different set.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was playing this again last night and after getting "good" at ST over the years it staggers me how great this port is. The graphics are downgraded but the gameplay is 99% there (minus various glitches that allow combos you couldn't do in the arcade). You can jump right back and forth between this version and the CPS2.

And the thing is about this version is it isn't really a straight port of Super. It's a port of The Tournament Battle, but since it has turbo speed it ends up playing a lot like ST. Three stars might even be a tad faster than turbo 3 on Japanese ST (X).

Yoshiki Okamoto wanted the SNES to get a port of ST but higher-ups (Tsujimoto, probably) decided to go with the 3do.
I think the SNES could probably have handled a good port of ST since all they needed to do was include the super moves and rebalance the game. ST has an extra move per character and that might have created some memory limitations but I think they could have worked around it.

>>9641541
Because its design philosophy contradicts itself. Your goal is to get to the goal post at the end of each stage, but you also have the goal of slowly looking around each level (and each time version of each level) looking for ways to time-travel and destroy machines. Interesting idea, but it's relegated to a minor mechanic that you doesn't really earn you anything and it kills the pacing. But at the same time if you just ignore the time travel optional bullshit then the levels are all really short and brainless.

If they really wanted to go head-first into the whole idea of traveling around exploring levels, they should've made it a critical aspect of the game rather than an optional side feature.

This would be true if ti wasn't for the rest of 2D Sonic games having that. Try playing S3&K normally and you'll not even see most of the level design as early as Angel Island, leaving some levels to be seen as annoying pace-breakers rather than anything of worth. On the other hand, if you go out and explore, you will find out that all of the zones are large in size and have tons of secrets, including the Giant Rings you want to find for the good ending, but that will kill the pace. Sonic games as a whole become brainless if you just speed through them (which all of the originals allow) and leave the decision whether the player wants to bother with the game's levels or not - if they do, try to get better times or explore the levels, if they don't, well maybe they'll have fun either way.

Also, good futures are cooler than super forms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Outside of modding in a DCHDMI/DCDigital, the best adapter is the Kaico (or the latest revision from Bitfunx as it's just a Kaico rebadged for cheaper) as it pulls directly from the 480p VGA, and outputs 480p. The only downside is it only supports games compatible with VGA out. Anything else will use composite signal and look like dogshit (Pound). If you have a SCART capable display, SCART cables are a great option too. But remember, some games can be patched to support VGA, but ones like BangaiO have no vga fix cause it's native 240p

SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

>>9642804
Mario Tennis runs at 30 fps. It means that, if the whole scene is around 2000 polygons, then we have 60000 polygons per second. Okay, let's say the court has additional 1000 polygons, which is unlikely. Then we have 90000 polygons per second. N64 specs suggest that it can run almost twice as much - 160000 polygons per second. Thus Mario Tennis is far from having the biggest polygon per second number.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Spyro 1 > 2 = 3

Spyro 1 was the peak of the series because it executed all the ideas it wanted to, without any excess baggage or dead weight to detract from them, and had the best aesthetic/musical direction.

The subsequent games all just tacked on gimmicks and annoying new characters that detracted from the gameplay. Spyro 2 suffers especially by introducing the hand-holding linear objectives for each level, instead of just allowing the player to explore- Thus the game lost the core of its success.

Crash 2 > 1 > 3.

Crash 2 builds on and improves on everything that made the first game great, without losing focus on the core platforming mechanics. It is the ideal sequel, that only offers more of the good stuff, and doesn't introduce anything to take away from it.

Crash 3 introduced a ton of dogshit gimmicks and lost focus on what had made the earlier games successful. It is much like Spyro 2 and 3 in that regard.

Yes, the FOV in parts with pre rendered backgrounds is usually very big, with cameras far away from the characters.
This is why models are the way they are, there was no technical reason why they couldn't have used battle models outside of battles.

It is because they kept with the tradition of older FF games: all of them except 6 have closer FOV and more detailed characters in battle than they do in the world. They simply adapted that to 3D.

FF8 broke away from the tradition but as a result you have a much greater percentage of camera point of views that are closer to the characters, using scrolling backgrounds more when the characters move around.

posts.name: Anonymous

Both are great
The GCN library is way the fuck deeper than the N64
It was also an era where Nintendo was doing a bunch of weird and interesting things with their IPs, so you got stuff like Metroid Prime, Mario Strikers, Luigi's Mansion, WarioWare and then new IPs like Pikmin and Eternal Darkness
On top of that you got Animal Crossing and Fire Emblem representation in the west, and significantly better third party support over the N64.

So to me it's like, yeah if I picked the top 5 games of the N64 to go head to head with the top 5 games from the GCN, the N64 would probably come out on top. But the sheer weight of the GCN's library pretty handily puts it on top over the N64 overall.

It's funny though I've been a Gamecube supporter since it launched, I bought FE: Path of Radiance and Paper Mario TTYD on launch, I was one of the poor bastards who had to wait an extra month to play Twilight Princess because I wasn't super interested in the Wii. So take that all into account when I say: I think the recent deification of the Gamecube is a massive over correction. It was an awesome console at the time and I don't think it deserved to be as eclipsed by the PS2 as it was, but holy FUCK do people put it up on a pedestal these days.

>>9633014
I got SM64 Christmas 96 and OoT in fall of 98 with my allowance, so yes I was there. I'm not saying they're bad games, I'm saying from a more objective perspective they aren't revolutionary. Virtually no games copied the SM64 camera frankly a good thing, everyone was copying the Quake and Tomb Raider cameras instead and things evolved from there. Z-targeting in OoT was a nice evolution for melee, but that's all it was. Z-targeting without movement was already in Megaman Legends, and Z-targeting with movement was already in Tomb Raider, so all OoT did was adapt it for melee with relative direction inputs. Again, a nice evolution, but obviously not revolutionary.

N64 was my favorite console since 1996. However I’ve been playing the Gamecube a lot since last year and noticed that a lot of the N64 games I loved have Gamecube sequels and ports, some better some worse. Let’s look at the list of the best N64 games:

>Ocarina of Time
- Ported, with a bonus master quest version
>Majora’s Mask
- Ported
>Mario Kart 64
- Sequel (Double Dash) is better
> Super Smash Bros
- Sequel (Melee) is better
>Goldeneye & Perfect Dark
- Timesplitters 2 is almost as good, plus you get Timesplitters 3 and you also get 5 James Bond games
>Rogue Squadron
- sequel is better
>Super Mario 64
- sequel is not as good, good enough though
>San Francisco Rush
- ported

Anyways, you pretty much get an at least decent followup, if not better version, of every great N64 game.

On top of this you have, with a Gameboy Player, access to 3 Gameboy generations, and through that ports of the best NES and SNES games (and that’s not even counting the compilations)

And on too of all that, you get RE4 and Metroid Prime 1&2

I can’t believe I’m saying this, but the Gamecube really is the better console. The amount of Zelda, Resident Evil, Sonic, Mega Man, and Mario games you can play on that thing is just mind blowing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gen 2 has a great aesthetic, probably because it's simply building off Gen 1 but optimizing it for the GBC, making it very charming and pretty.

Still, I can't get behind the general praise for them as superior games. I don't think they're bad games, but they simply don't play as smoothly and seamlessly as an experience and there are many reasons for this, such as the day and night exclusive mons....an interesting gimmick that was impressive and immersive the first time you witnessed it as a child, but really puts a damper on things ultimately forcing you to schedule when you play or stop playing the game. Pokemon selection offers more Pokemon this time around yet it FEELS like there's less somehow, it's bizarre, it feels like a struggle to get a nice team going earlier on when you want to, Crystal "the favorite" even takes away your one option for the electric type, not to mention the lack of easily accessible stones means even some of the Pokemon you might choose won't evolve unless you happen to save the "right" phone numbers aka go look up a guide, or wait till endgame...and there's another thing, the second half of the game feels all out of wack, you reach the new Elite 4 too quickly, and the game after that point just feels kinda half assed, one of the few things everyone can agree was irritating about Gen 1, being forced to use unwanted HMs or resort to HM slaves is double downed on in Gen 2 adding multiple new HMs you never wanted ensuring you MUST have a HM slave this time and late game too, it's worse than cut and flash which you don't need once you get fly, there's just so many little things that make these games a bit rough

One of my biggest vidya-related regrets is not having played the Gen 2 Pokemon games when they came out. I played the absolute shit out of Gen 1, and was stoked when I heard about Gen 2. I did replay Gen 1 a couple of times during that time frame, though, so maybe I just turned into a stuffy Genwunner in record time, I dunno. Whatever the case, It took like a decade before I touched another Pokemon game, namely Emerald, Lead Green and Platinum. I did get Soul Silver, but I think having played the previous three nigh back-to-back burned me out, with the last straw being me forgetting to save and turning it off after hours of progress (I was tired and possibly drunk lol). I know I can always pick it up, whether the original or the DS remake, but I always get this nagging feeling that I already "missed the boat" on it and any magic it held would be lost on me, sort of like when I played ALttP after OoT, and so I always hesitate and decide against it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9628424
Slowking at least can be seen as a course correction to Slowbro excelling in stats that he can't use(attack/defense for a Water/Psychic Pokemon when those types are still special based only)

A lot of the game design in GSC seems like GF didn't consider cultural differences outside Japan. babies are there for the cute factor. Stuff like Pokemon being kept until the last areas of Kanto seem like they expected more experienced players to get them, and trade them to newer/younger players out of the kindness of their heart. Or that one person who found that rare pokemon would breed it and spread it around. And with the trade evolution, they expected kids to actually trust each other to do fair trades with strangers; where as here it feels like everyone was so paranoid to trade with others they bought second games, or only traded more valued Pokemon with family members
It goes back to them expecting Mew to be traded around, as opposed to everyone keeping the one Mew they could get. Its almost like they ere trying a social experiment to see how far a trade would travel.

I think part of the reason pokemon cards caught on so much here in the US is because they were easier to carry around, play, and trade than Gameboy. You could hide cards in school, or take them out with you, with gameboys you'd worry about them getting confiscated. a lot of the US is also far less dense so its harder to hang out outside of school with lots of kids, let alone strangers to trade with outside your circle. Every kid I knew who liked Pokemon that I met with almost never carried their gameboy on him Where as Japan it seems like everyone was just caring a GB all the time, probably because they had more self control as to not play it in the middle of class like an American kid might.

also unless you're still dwelling in your mom's basement, you should know how work environments go. Managers and bosses often have no clue what really goes and how things are really made, even colleagues often don't know about each other's work, and facts and rumours are often distorted. Video game companies are no exception. >>9620369
Gen 1 and 2 were created from a man's own childhood experiences exploring his childhood Japan looking for insects to collect. He wanted to share that sense of wonder and adventure with a generation of children who were less likely to go outside and explore. Gen 2 was a refinement of the already-classic Gen 1 with a number of new features that made the world seem more alive, like the clock and calendar feature. The series loses that special feeling after that because that man stepped down as lead director. By Gen 3, the series was churning out titles not because the director had something to say or an experience to share, but simply because Nintendo wanted to make more money from it. The Brand™ was refined to get rid of any perceived rough edges like real-life animals or locations being referenced and sterilized to ensure marketability. The new director was simply designing the titles around what he thought would sell more units.

posts.com: Can I combine 2-3 hacks in the game? Or will it break? I want Simon's quest with normal advice, double hearts and no floor traps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Sometimes it's possible, but it depends on how each patch was constructed. If one or more of them start moving data around that conflicts with the other patches it'll break. If there's no documentation about it then the only way to know for sure would be to try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Use Lunar IPS and make sure the "Create a log file" option is ticked, then check the log files and see if that no two hacks replaces the same addresses (offset + size)

in most cases if there are is no overlap then it should be compatible, unless as pointed out, one of the hacks moved data around and a change in another hack still thinks the data is in the original place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625168
Programmer decides ROM read speed, but if it is too much for the cart it returns shit instead of the expected values.
So you enable the "fast" ROM read speed (the speed used by almost if not all commercial games), you read some data from ROM and if returned values are not what you expect you are using a piece of shit cart.

>>9632860
Did you know?

In Japan those kinds of cabinets are considered "table" cabinets even though they are not cocktail cabinets.
Sega Astro City, Blast City, and basically all "candy" cabinets are still considered "table" cabinets. And the games that run in them are considered a different category of arcade game compared to the other side, which is "upright" or "cockpit" arcade games.
In the USA a game like Street Fighter II in a big blue cabinet would be considered an upright cabinet, but in Japan that same cab would be considered a "table" cabinet. Doesn't matter how big it is. Even a Megalo 50 running Virtua Fighter 3 on a 50" screen is a "table" cabinet.

Games like Outrun or Time Crisis are considered "cockpit" and "upright" games. But not only that they are considered the true "arcade" games compared to "table" games which are a little different and have a lineage that goes back to the Space Invader's boom and game parlors more than what we in the west thing of as an arcade. They are more of a lounge game you stop by every day after work and school and play many times compared to a more expensive "upright" you play only every so often unless you are a dedicated "arcade gamer".

Additionally, standard JAMMA "table" games could be readily played on control boxes (superguns) at home while an "upright" would be quite difficult to set up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642592
SaGa is not FF at all but is instead a separate series of RPGs developed by square. The best way to define the SaGa games is that they are very heavily focused on gameplay and on having unusual systems. For that reason they are often as innovative as they are frustrating. The lead designer is Akitpshi Kawazu, who is also famous (or infamous) as designer of FF2. Another trademark is unpredictability; Several of his games seem designed to be difficult or impossible to easily figure out or to manipulate. Believe I've read before that his philosophy is that games are another universe, and so they should be a complex universe of rules and events that aren't always obvious, or else the world ceases to be a real world and is reduced to a simple toy for the player's amusement. This leads to designs that include obtuse methods or entirely hidden systems that control things without the player immediately knowing about them. If you've played other games be designed then you'll know what I mean (Crystal Chronicles on gamecube, Last Remnant, and WildCard come to mind).

I'm not an expert but that's my understanding. The games are often strange but have a very unique style that you won't often see. Series is worth trying out, the first game is rudimentary but still interesting. You'll find if you play them that sequels get more refined, but also that things only stay static for a short period and different entries are often wildly different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Karma: Immortal Wrath aka Eternal Karma. Supposedly the first 3D RPG made in South Korea. There doesn't exist a retail English version, but it was released in Germany (among Japan and Italy, I think). The German version has a notorious game breaking bug, which I was actually able to work around.
There's also an incomplete English translation in the game data. All in pretty low quality. I guess the developer translated it from Korean to English and the publisher then translated it to German. I was thinking about re-inserting the English script and re-translating the missing parts myself, but I just didn't find the time and motivation to do so yet. The game is rather mediocre but I have some nostalgia for it.

I played a vertical scrolling shooter on an arcade cabinet in the mid nineties, i can't describe it much but i could swear the cabinet had the name UN SQUADRON on it.
looking on youtube it seems that UN squadron is a side scroller so i'm just wondering if there was ever a vertical scroller that had this name or had anything to do with the UN squadron games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642249
I'm inclined to think you've got multiple memories blended together. U.N. Squadron is indeed a horizontal shmup and I don't think it was a part of any further game series. The title in Japan is Area 88, and it was a game based on a manga series of the same name running at the time.
I do have another suspicion. The cabinet could have been repurposed. The cheapest way to do so would be with a game that runs on the same board. Area 88 ran off a CPS-1 board. For vertical shmups on a CPS-1, that would mean the actual game was either 1941 or Varth: Operation Thunderstorm. Look up some gameplay on those to see if they ring any bells.
I don't have much confidence in my knowledge on arcade hardware so if anyone knows I've said something wrong, let me know.

>>9638967
The 64DD wasn't a terrible plan. During the early days of the N64 the games were pretty small even by cartridge standards. Around 8MBs. The idea behind the 64DD was that it would be an inexpensive way to get 64MB games onto the system when and if that extra space was necessary. The price of cartridge space dropped precipitously in the interim though making the floppies completely obsolete. The PC equivalent was ZIP disks, which filled the gap between 1.44" floppies and CD-R back when people needed more space but CD burners were still pretty expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9639063
>There's a good reason to use floppy over MROM, and that is cost and availability.
Not in the console space though. MaskROM was already matching floppies in capacity during most of the 90s. That's what killed the FDS. Nintendo was planning to transition all Famicom software to diskette after Super Mario Bros. but suddenly maskROM prices came down, extra hardware could be added to the board that exceeded the FDS's abilities, and piracy was less of a concern overall than the comparatively easy to pirate floppy disks, so everything switched back to cartridge. It's only as you got into the tail end of the 1990s that larger capacity floppies started being much cheaper than comparatively sized maskROM but even that changed once the N64 started seeing 64MB games like Resident Evil 2.

Plus the extra space was not really helpful. The majority of a game didn't need all that much space. It certainly didn't need hundreds of MBs. What took up the space on CDs were higher res textures, CD audio, and FMV. So a floppy disk that could do upwards of 100MBs as opposed to a cartridge at 32MBs wouldn't be that helpful. Especially on the N64 where the bottleneck wasn't storage space but the pitiful texture cache. There weren't that many games where the issue was the lack of a couple dozen MBs. You either had a game that fit on a cartridge or you were filling a CD with stuff that absolutely required a 650MB CD.

If you think about it, a floppy is the worst of both worlds. It doesn't have the massive space benefit of a CD but you can't add cart-side hardware to supplement the system's hardware like you can with a cartridge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Smash was huge when it was new. Obviously things didn't move as fast in 99 without the internet and "gamer culture" as it is today, but by that summer almost every kid with an N64 was playing this game. The kid with the Nintendo power subscription was super excited about it and we played the hell out of it at his birthday party. Pokemon craze was still in full swing at the time and just having the pokeballs as an item with a bunch of different monsters to come out sold the game on it's own. I had friends in my neighborhood who would all come over and play 4-player (passing off the 3rd party controller to the youngest of course). I had another friend that I would regularly see and we would "competitively" play no item 12-stock matches on Sector Z as Kirby and Fox. Melee is more fondly remembered, but I'd say at the time 64 was an even bigger deal to general audiences. It was exactly the kind of game that made the 64 stand out from the playstation (which had quickly become the cool console of the gen with Metal Gear Solid and Final Fantasy), and it's a big reason why Nintendo was able to stay afloat along with introducing a ton of people to games like Metroid, F-Zero, and Earthbound for the first time.

Yeah, easiest way is to edit your save file. The best way of editing Pokemon in any games is with PKHeX:
https://projectpokemon.org/home/files/file/1-pkhex/
This software is the gold standard for everything Pokemon, comes with integrated legality checks and a bunch of other cool shit. You edit your team, save changes to (or export a new one) save file, open it in emulator - boom, done.

You could also trade Pokemon with someone else online (or yourself locally, running two emulator programs at the same time) since it's possible to emulate the game link cable, but that's the long, autistic way of going about it that I mention only in case editing the save file goes against your moral values or some shit.

>>9633585
Because all DOS platforming sidescrollers before this were complete shit. PCs back then didn't have quite the power to do smooth scrolling without clever optimization, which John Carmack thought up. Apparently people were too stupid to load up the relevant assets into memory for each level and keep them there, nor did anyone else think to program the software to not constantly fucking redraw things like all the solid color background pixels when things moved, and other things which didn't actually change.

It's true that Commander Keen isn't anything really special today, particularly if you had any home console of the late 80s or early 90s, but here was a platformer which was almost as smooth as console ones, and the first 10 levels were for free, overall it was decent while being technically impressive. The game was unprecedented for PCs at the time, and it was an easy gift to your kid if you already had a computer for office work at home. Not too expensive to get him the full version somewhere down the line, or for him to save up to it with some chores, maybe throw in some gamepad too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the legacy of speccy.

Back then game design on speccy (if it's a game you can traverse/explore) was to just make ridiculous maze-like levels where you're supposed to meander around forever trying to find three of some key item to progress to another maze-like level.
Very rarely do these levels make any sort of sense otherwise.

Since most of european devs started off with speccy this philosophy continued into the DOS/Amiga game designs later.

In Japan however the main philosophy was to make levels that are more straightforward but "difficult" in the way the challenge is tailor made to make a skillful run once you get the hang of the main gameplay mechanics.

>>9626462
>Looks so 80's style, almost like a movie.
They very deliberately invoked that kind of vibe. The original AOF was one of the few fighting games of the time that wasn't about a bunch of people joining a fighting tournament, instead it was about two bros beating people up in shady parts of town looking for a kidnapped girl, a plot far more common in beat'em ups. I almost wish AOF had been a beat'em up, it would have been a great one for sure and wouldn't have suffered all the direct comparisons to SF2 that caused a lot of people to look down on it. And the characters could still have been used in KOF anyway.

>>9630584
Nah all those were pretty lame. It's such a shame too because SNK obviously put a lot of effort into AOF3, it's quite possibly the prettiest game on the Neo Geo. The sprites are huge and the rotoscoped animations are fluid as fuck, some stage have some fancy light and shadow effects, the gameplay was vastly improved from the previous games with a really satisfying combo system. But for some reason they chose to put all of that into a side story with a bunch of randos and the incredible latino Hulk for a boss instead of following up on the plot threads laid down in the previous game which had specifically namedropped Jeff Bogard to set up his confrontation with Geese. That's what AOF3 should have been about.

posts.com:
I dont remember where I heard this but one thing that might’ve stopped AOF3 from taking off is that knockdowns took way to long to recover from, which seems minor until you’re a hundred rounds in and getting fed up with it. I know about the otg hits you can do but everyone always stays down for like five seconds and it breaks the flow of things.

This mostly only applies to the autistic tourney player side of fighting games, since they’re the ones who are playing CONSTANTLY so a little thing that can add up like this becomes a bigger deal.

As a more casual player I liked AoF3 quite a lot. Went through everyone’s story mode last year and had a very fun time. Really enjoyable single player quest for a fighting game.

I really liked the single player stuff for all the AoFs and FFs actually. KoF sort of went too far with the ancient gods and family bloodline and clone army nonsense, but the world of FF/AoF/Garou was a cool one I wanted to see more of. I really like that corny 80s/90s streetbrawler vibe they had.

As far as the right stick goes, I can't actually think of any PSX game that uses the right stick and doesn't just assume you aren't going to be actively using the face buttons. Like even in Gran Turismo you can use the right stick instead of X and Square and yeah Triangle and Circle are still reverse and e-brake, but you also aren't using the x-axis of the right stick at all so the total number of inputs still hasn't changed. On the flip side I can't defend going from 8 to 6 buttons, and being free from having to support the digital controller From was already making PS2 launch window games that used all 10 buttons.

This.
>X - red, no (position swapped to right button)
>O - green, yes (position swapped to bottom button as this is the button you're going to be pressing most when dealing with dialogues and your thumb tends to naturally rest on this central button)
>Square - blue-gray, a combination of the most common menu system colors, open menu (position swapped to top button)
>Triangle - gold. As this is the most comfortable button to roll your thumb onto while pressing O(bottom) to jump, this is your action/slash/shoot button (position swapped to left button)

>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9628239
Putting it into order it goes like this:
>Evil Energy -> Wily Virus (EE + robot reprogramming algorithm) -> Maverick Virus (Wily Virus optimized to explot Reploid design flaws) -> Sigma Virus (Maverick Virus fused with Sigma's digitized AI at the end of X1) -> Zero Virus (Sigma Virus fused with the virus smuggled by Dynamo into the Eurasia space colony and Zero's AI) -> Nightmare Virus (Zero Virus + DNA Program successfully reverse-engineered by Gate) -> Copy Chip (DNA Program of Sigma and many other old Reploids rendered inert and implemented into New Gen Reploids as to make use of the abilities it grants users)
It may sound silly in a work of fiction, but do remember how many strains of COVID we've gotten in like 3 years.
Putting this into perspective, EE being a sapient entitity does lend to the idea that it keeps consuming hosts and evolving much like a virus, jumping from robot to robot, system to system, mechaniloid to mechaniloid, iteration to iteration. Given the X series' overarching theme of robot free will, it does seem like the virus itself is acting on its own free will in a very twisted way, by rending others of their own.
If Wily turning himself into a cyborg holds true or at least plausible, the virus may have even taken over him. After all, his real body was never found. It may even hint at the reason why X and Zero are not allowed to go near the locations where their capsules were found.

Sue Kasper (main composer) submitted General MIDI files on floppy disk to Brian Conrad (composer and main sound engineer) who would then play them back using either a Sound Canvas (Roland SC-55) or a Boss Dr. Synth DS-330 (a variant of the Roland SC-33, itself a variant of the SC-55). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9629926
Mostly this, but I would actually say the control scheme of the original is the only reason to play it at this point. Many shit on it because it's so unique and has a pretty deep learning curve until you're used to it. But once you are, no other game is like it. You really feel the difference in the weapons, swinging back and forth with the greatsword versus stabbing up and down with the lance. I understand the people who didn't like it, but to me it's sublime and the thing I missed most about the game on it's sequels.

I am a monster hunter super fan though, it's probably my favorite series of games ever. I maxed the clock at 999 hours on the original long, long before I stopped playing and other than Tri on the Wii and the World/Rise games I've put at least several hundred hours into every one.

Playing the original now would be kind of sad because the online was such a major component but it's still an awesome game regardless and the offline game is quite a complete experience in it's own right. If you like it there's plenty more Monster Hunter out there to jump into including Generations Ultimate which is basically the best the series has ever been and still has a decent player base.

That said, the player bases as in all online games are always a little funny. One thing we still joke about is the first time I actually got my PS2 hooked up online. I almost always use greatsword, but happened to have a hammer on me when I came into the hub. I was HR1 so an online newbie, and the first thing said was "hey welcome to MH! Hammers suck btw" because there was an early (wrong impression that they did) but neither happened to notice the hammer I had was the Breathcore which is the most powerful one in the game.

>>9638517
Because basically the output values of a legit N64 stick are fucking weird and max values don't line up with max values on most 'normal' joysticks. But emulators compensate for this by assuming you're using a normal stick and then mapping those values to what an N64 game would expect. The problem is if you use a real N64 controller then this adjustment is being applied for the one instance where it's not needed.

>>9641434
Hellfire is an expansion pack for the original Diablo that was not developed by the original team. Sierra, the publisher, wanted to get more use from their publishing rights so they had one of their studios produce the expansion in Blizzard's stead.
It adds some neat things (oils, running in town) and extends the life of the game but the content is generally not as good as the base game.

The SMS controller was quite limited. Two buttons(third on console), vs four on controller.

The NES ended up having such a huge library too and more variety although this meant more shit games to wade through.

Obviously the sound issues like we’ve been discussing.

Developers did learn to work around the NES limitations or cheat with mappers.

>>9639537
inaccurate; The designer was instructed to make the console more trendy and less toy-like. The design was also changed so that no one would try putting liquid containers on top of it; NoA had to repair a number of NES units that had been used as tables for drinks, cereal bowls, soda cans, etc. This was a big part of redesigning the sufami so that no one would think of putting drinks on top of an SNES.

If you're angry about the design changes then at least know the correct reasons for them. The designer's opinion mattered little in the design change, for one thing. If you want to be angry at anyone, be angry at the bigwigs of NoA at the time, like Howard Lincoln or Minoru Arakawa.

Article starts on page 44 in case you're curious. https://archive.org/details/NintendoPowerVolume25/page/n43/mode/2up

NP #25, June 1991 issue.

posts.com:
While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As a console peasant growing up in the 90s without a PC, the only shooters I had access to were Goldeneye, Perfect Dark, and maybe Rainbow 6. Rainbow 6 was too tactical for my childhood mind to fully enjoy.
When my friend invited me over to their house to play their brand new Xbox, my 13 year old mind was blown away. High quality music, amazing graphics, huge levels in both co-op and frag matches, good selection of guns including alien weaponry and they all feel different thanks to the built in rumble pak, vehicles both human and alien that significantly increased your power.
So we hop into multiplayer and it's myself and 3 other friends, and then his brother and his 3 friends can somehow connect to my friends Xbox and we have a 4v4?! Amazing times were had. I'll never experience those moments again for the first time ever.
So basically just nostalgia.
